Founded Sept 2016 by 3 Valencia families. All Valencia students guaranteed a place at La Pinada for Primary+. School bus available (€175/month return). Early bird (from 8am, €65/month) and Afternoon Club (until 18:00, €80/month) available. Secular, co-ed school. AMI-inspired Montessori. ~10 years of experience (as of 2025/26).

column24: Main campus for full K–18 pathway. First school in Spain with BREEAM Excellent + Green Building Council 4 Leaves certification. 5,000m² sustainable building (S-shaped plan by Gradolí & Sanz Arquitectes, 2017–2019) set among pine trees adjacent to En Dolça ravine. 30,000m² total site. ~€4M investment. 70% energy savings vs. conventional buildings; landscaped roof; wood & clay construction. Children enter via elevated timber walkways through pine forest. New secondary/sixth form facilities under construction for 2025/26. Zubi Labs co-working hub for Year 12–13 students. Located ~8.6km from Valencia centre; school bus available. Secular, co-ed school. Founded by 3 Valencia families.

Certified 'Exzellente Deutsche Auslandsschule' by BLI (Bund-Länder-Inspektion). Free Selectividad (PCE) prep classes offered in Classes 11–12 (2 subjects included; additional subjects €50/semester each).

column14: German educational system (Begegnungsschule / 'encounter school' model): emphasis on academic rigour, bilingual German-Spanish development, intercultural understanding, and personal responsibility. High proportion of Spanish students alongside German nationals. Exchange programmes with schools in Germany and France. Music association and sports association actively connect students, parents, and alumni.
column22: €5,380–€5,925/year (2025/26): Kindergarten €5,925/yr (€592.50/month × 10); Classes 1–4 €5,925/yr (€592.50/month); Classes 5–8 €5,380/yr (€538/month); Classes 9–10 €5,875/yr (€587.50/month); Class 11 €5,925/yr (€592.50/month); Class 12 €5,925/yr (€658.33/month × 9). Matrícula (enrolment): €1,700 (1st child), €1,530 (2nd), €1,360 (3rd+). Fianza (refundable deposit): €1,000. Sibling discounts: 10% (2nd), 20% (3rd), 30% (4th+) — not applicable to Kindergarten. Additional: SpaF (Spanish as foreign language) €765–€985/yr; digital media fee Classes 5–8 €190/yr. Comedor (lunch) billed separately.
column24: One of the oldest international schools in Valencia, originally founded in 1909 with 4 German pupils. Closed during WWI (1914), Spanish Civil War (1936), and post-WWII (1945); secretly resumed in private homes in 1946. Current heritage-listed Modernist building (by Dieter Weisse, Peter Müller, Pablo Navarro & Julio Trullenque) inaugurated 1961 on C/ Jaume Roig. 14,000m² campus occupying a full city block near the University of Valencia. Andreu Alfaro fountain sculpture in central courtyard; garden designed by Rubió i Tudurí. Part of the ZfA (Zentralstelle für das Auslandsschulwesen) network of German schools abroad. ~50–60 students graduate with Abitur annually. Strong alumni network. Exchange programmes with Germany (Hamburg) and France. Music school and sports association on site. Mediterranean-based lunch menu with local products. Occasional scholarships available (at discretion of scholarship commission). Certified 'Exzellente Deutsche Auslandsschule'. Central location walkable/bikeable for most students.

column9: Nursery (age 2), Pre-Kindergarten (PK3–PK4), Elementary School (Kindergarten–Grade 6), Middle School (Grades 7–8), High School (Grades 9–12). Three diploma pathways in Grades 11–12: American High School Diploma, Spanish Título de Bachillerato (via convalidation), and optionally the IB Diploma.
column10: American curriculum (US Common Core Standards) + Spanish National Standards + IB Diploma Programme (Grades 11–12, authorised since 2004). College-preparatory focus. 70+ course subjects in High School. MSA-CESS accredited (Middle States Association; current cycle through May 2027). Registered as Centro Extranjero with Spanish Ministry of Education (Code: 46016610).
column11: English is the primary language of instruction; Spanish language programme integrated throughout all grades (minimum 1 hour daily); world languages from Grade 7

column14: Inquiry-based learning; IB philosophy (critical thinking, global citizenship, international-mindedness); American college-preparatory approach; PBIS (Positive Behavioral Intervention and Supports) in Elementary; workshop model (Teachers College, Columbia University) for literacy; student agency and collaboration emphasised. World Language Acquisition aligned with CEFR and ACTFL standards. Model United Nations programme and global student exchanges.
column22: €7,246–€9,545/year (2025/26, per International Schools Database). Breakdown by stage: Nursery ~€7,246; Elementary ~€6,047–€7,200; Middle School ~€7,500–€8,000; High School (Gr 9–12) ~€7,790–€9,545. First-year total ~€12,571 incl. one-time fees. Capital fee: €1,500 (refundable share). Enrolment fee: €1,200. Bus: ~€1,620/year. Books: €316–€477 depending on grade. Sibling discounts may apply — contact admissions. Lunch billed separately.
column23: ~700–800 students (estimated; Glassdoor lists 51–200 employees; majority of students enter at age 2–3 and stay through graduation at 18). Not officially published — contact school for exact figure.
column24: One of the oldest international schools in Valencia (founded 1980 with MSA support). 45th anniversary celebrated in 2025. Located in Puçol's Los Monasterios gated estate, ~20–25km north of Valencia city centre (~30 min drive), in the foothills of the Sierra Calderona mountains. 32,000m² campus with three parks, artificial turf playing field, and swimming pool. MSA-CESS accredited since founding (current accreditation through May 2027; next cycle underway toward 2027). IB Diploma Programme since 2004 — one of the first two schools to implement IB in Valencia. IB results consistently above world average. Graduates earn up to 3 diplomas (American, Spanish Bachillerato, IB). Strong university placement record (top-tier Spanish and international universities). Member of MAIS (Mediterranean Association of International Schools), ASCD, and ECIS. Director: Michael L. Smith. ASV+ co-curricular programme (sports teams, STEM, arts). AENOR sustainability certification for lunch service. Bus routes from Valencia, Rocafort, Godella, La Cañada, Sagunto. Summer programmes available (STEAM Camp, Discover America, Level Up Your English). Eco-School project active. Rolling admissions year-round.

column4: Carrer Mas de León 5, 46530 Puçol, Valencia, Spain

column9: Baby Caxton (ages 1–2), Nursery (age 3), Reception (age 4), Primary (Years 1–6, ages 5–11), Secondary (Years 7–11, ages 11–16, iGCSE), Sixth Form (Years 12–13, ages 16–18, A-Levels). Uniform compulsory through Year 11; Sixth Form follows a dress code.
column10: British National Curriculum throughout all stages. iGCSE (Year 10–11) and A-Levels (Year 12–13) via Edexcel and AQA exam boards. Spanish compulsory curriculum subjects (Lengua, Valenciano, Ciencias Sociales, Religión) integrated to allow dual qualification: A-Levels + Spanish ESO/Bachillerato (via convalidation) + Spanish PCE (Pruebas de Competencia Específica) for Spanish university access. BSO (British Schools Overseas) accredited with 'Excellent' rating in ALL areas — first awarded 2017 by Cambridge Education, renewed 2019 by ISI (Independent Schools Inspectorate), and 2022. Listed by UK DfE as a school of reference outside Britain. Member of NABSS and ACADE.
column11: English is the primary language of instruction (80% of teaching staff are British); Spanish and Valencian for compulsory Spanish curriculum subjects taught by Spanish staff
column12: English, Spanish, Valencian, French, German, Chinese (Mandarin)
column13: IT/computing taught from Year 1 to Year 11 following British model (computational thinking, programming, robotics). ICT suites and robotics classroom on campus. Specific BYOD/1:1 device policy details not publicly confirmed — the school implemented a 'new technology approach' in consultation with families and educational specialists to promote productive use while minimising risks. Contact school for current grade-by-grade device policy.
column14: British education model with emphasis on values (motto: 'Honeste Vivere' — Live Honourably), creativity, inquiry, autonomy, and critical thinking. Pastoral care system with dedicated co-head of academics and co-head of pastoral in secondary (restructured from single head role). PBIS-style positive behaviour framework. Classmate-mentor system for new students. Experienced SENCos in both primary and secondary; psychologist and speech therapist in primary. Strong emphasis on emotional wellbeing, values education (respect, resilience, responsibility), and personal development.

Exam fees charged additionally for Years 11, 12, and 13. School bus available (20+ routes covering Valencia and Castellón province). Lunch (comedor) with onsite kitchens — billed separately. Exact stage-by-stage breakdown: contact school or visit caxtoncollege.com/en/admissions/fees. Note: ISD range €7,780–€9,860 is significantly higher than original estimate of €600–700/month.
column23: ~1,200+ students (estimated from: Good Schools Guide notes Reception regularly full with waiting lists; 109 pupils in most recent Sixth Form cohort alone; 66% Spanish + 20% international from 45+ nationalities; campus is 42,000–45,000m²). Not officially published — contact school for exact figure.
column24: One of the most highly regarded British schools in the Valencia region. Founded 1987 by the Gil-Marqués family; current principal: Marta Gil Marqués (since August 2023, youngest of five sisters; succeeded Amparo Gil). Motto: 'Honeste Vivere' (Live Honourably). 42,000m² (some sources cite 45,000m²) purpose-built campus surrounded by orange groves, ~18km north of Valencia city, ~3km from Mediterranean. Exceptional facilities: 9 science labs; William Caxton Library (35,000+ publications, full-time librarians); theatre (330 seats, sound/lighting booth); Caxton Sports Centre with fitness rooms; 2 gymnasiums; outdoor + heated indoor 25m swimming pools; 2 eight-a-side astroturf football pitches; sports pavilion with regulation basketball court (opened December 2024, professional-grade, homologated to Liga ACB standards); outdoor basketball court; 2 tennis courts; padel court; 6 outdoor learning areas in Early Years/Primary; 5 playground areas; specialist art/music classrooms in secondary; Caxton Young Artists Gallery; 4 dining rooms (age-differentiated) with onsite kitchens; clinic with full-time nurse + nursing assistant. School transport: 20+ bus routes covering Valencia, Sagunto, Castellón. Academic results: >85% achieve A*–C in A-Levels; 2024/25 average Sixth Form grade 8.6/10; average Spanish university admission grade 12.3. Pearson Outstanding Learner Awards recipients. ~75% of graduates attend Spanish universities (most popular: IE, Universitat de València); ~25% attend universities abroad — alumni at Oxford, Cambridge, Imperial College, Harvard, Columbia, Dartmouth, MIT, Berkeley, LSE, UCL, King's College London. 2024 cohort: 1 student to Oxford; others to Imperial (Aerospace Engineering, Chemical Engineering), King's College London (Economics), UCL (Biochemistry). 66% Spanish student body; ~20% international from 45+ nationalities. Boarding available via host families (international students). Club Deportivo for competitive-level sport. Summer English/sports camps (tennis, football). BSO 'Excellent' in all areas since 2017 (three consecutive inspections). ISI and Cambridge Education accredited. Good Schools Guide reviewed.

column4: Main Campus: C/ Filipinas, 37, 46006 València (also fronting Av. Peris i Valero, 57); BSV Nexus (Sixth Form): Av. Peris y Valero, 99, 46006 València

Sixth Form at BSV Nexus (Years 12–13, ages 16–18, AS/A-Levels). Dual qualification: A-Levels + Spanish Bachillerato.
column10: British National Curriculum (EYFS through A-Levels). Cambridge Assessment International Education (Cambridge IGCSE, AS & A-Level examinations). Also uses Oxford AQA and Pearson Edexcel exam boards. Spanish compulsory curriculum subjects (Lengua, Valenciano, Ciencias Sociales) integrated for ESO/Bachillerato dual qualification. Cambridge Checkpoint intermediate exams (end of Year 9). Recognised by both UK and Spanish educational authorities. Member of NABSS (National Association of British Schools in Spain). Common Sense School (digital citizenship). European Youth Parliament participant.
column11: English is the primary language of instruction; Spanish for required Spanish curriculum subjects (Lengua, Valenciano, Ciencias Sociales)

column13: 1:1 Digital Learning Programme: each student has their own digital device (tablets/laptops). All classrooms equipped with interactive touchscreens regardless of year group. Movable wall classrooms for flexible/collaborative learning. Common Sense School certified for digital citizenship and online safety. BSV has a dedicated Digital Learning Programme and Digital Leaders programme among students. Exact grade of introduction and device model — contact school to confirm current year-by-year rollout.
column14: British curriculum approach with emphasis on core values: respect, tolerance, creativity, initiative, personal effort. Character development programme. Wellbeing Programme. University & Career Guidance Programme. Academic Excellence Awards (50% fee reduction scholarship for outstanding Year 11 and Year 12 students). Outstanding Cambridge Learner Awards recipients since 2008/09 (including Top in the World, Top in Spain, and High Achievement awards). Music Programme with soundproofed practice cabins and individual instrument tuition. Duke of Edinburgh Award scheme participant. European Youth Parliament. Extra-curricular activities programme.

column22: OFFICIAL FEES 2025/26 (from bsvalencia.com, paid in 10 monthly instalments): EYFS (Pre-Nursery/Nursery/Reception): €715/month = €7,150/year. Primary (Years 1–6): €790/month = €7,900/year. Secondary (Years 7–11): €920/month = €9,200/year. Sixth Form (Years 12–13): €957/month = €9,570/year. Admission fee: €3,250 (first-time enrolment; €1,600 for siblings and Year 7–13 entries). Annual renewal: €445 (non-refundable). School materials: €242/term (€726/year). Transport: €199/month (optional). Dining room: €210/month (mandatory Pre-Nursery to Year 3). Morning Club: €25–€50/month. Afternoon Homework Club: €25–€50/month. School of Music: €790/year (33 classes). Textbooks invoiced separately in November. Uniform from El Corte Inglés.
column23: Not officially published. Estimated ~600–800+ students (70+ nationalities represented; two campuses; BSV Nexus 1,800m² for Sixth Form). Contact school for exact figure.
column24: ONLY British school in Valencia city centre (Ruzafa neighbourhood — walkable, public transport accessible). Founded 1992; part of Cognita Schools Group since January 2019 (Cognita operates 100+ schools worldwide incl. 7 in Spain). Two campuses ~5 min walk apart in Ruzafa: Main campus (C/ Filipinas 37) occupies nearly a full city block — EYFS, Primary, Secondary; BSV Nexus (Av. Peris y Valero 99) — 1,800m² purpose-built Sixth Form pre-university centre with 4 permanent classrooms, 4 flexible support rooms (movable walls), 2 labs, library, art room, cafeteria, multifunctional study space, 2 teacher rooms; BREEAM sustainability certification; abundant natural light, wood finishes, and greenery. Significant recent investment to expand/renovate both campuses. All classrooms equipped with interactive touchscreens. Outstanding Cambridge Learner Awards since 2008/09: Top in the World (AS PE; A-Level Spanish Lang & Lit), Top in Spain, High Achievement (AS French) — across IGCSE, AS, and A-Level subjects. Academic Excellence Awards: 50% fee reduction scholarships for top Year 11/12 students. Rankings: El Mundo top 12 international schools in Comunidad Valenciana; Forbes Best Schools in Spain; El Confidencial/Micole 3rd most requested private school in Spain; Micole top 100 Best Private Schools in Spain, top 25 in Valencia city, top 100 in Valencia region (2026). 70+ nationalities represented. Main limitation: limited outdoor/sports space due to city-centre location (noted by alumni reviews). Bus service available (optional, €199/month). Rolling admissions year-round; non-selective but requires academic records and interview. Summer school available. School of Music with soundproofed cabins. Duke of Edinburgh Award. European Youth Parliament.

column9: Foundation Stage / Nursery (age 3–5), Primary (Years 1–6, ages 5–11), Secondary (Years 7–11, ages 11–16, IGCSE/GCSE), Sixth Form (Years 12–13, ages 16–18, AS & A-Levels). Dual qualification: A-Levels + Spanish Bachillerato (via convalidation).
column10: Full British National Curriculum (UK) from Foundation to A-Levels. Accredited Cambridge and Edexcel examination centre. Cambridge IGCSE (Year 10–11) and AS/A-Level (Year 12–13). Spanish compulsory subjects (Lengua y Literatura Española, Ciencias Sociales, Valenciano) integrated for dual qualification. Member of NABSS (National Association of British Schools in Spain). Authorised by Spanish Ministry of Education as Centro Extranjero — qualifications recognised in both UK and Spain.

German is NOT listed as a taught language. This appears to be an error in the original data.
column13: No public grade-by-grade device rollout policy found. School has IT rooms on both campuses. Contact school for current technology/device policy details.
column14: British educational approach run as a teacher cooperative. Core values: respect, dialogue, tolerance, freedom, responsibility, teamwork, participation, critical thinking. Secular and pluralist ethos. Historical roots in Montessori and Freinet pedagogy (1976 founding), combined with Piaget's developmental psychology principles. Focus on individual development across human, emotional, intellectual, artistic, and physical dimensions. Strong community and family-oriented atmosphere with personal attention. Small school ethos (~570 pupils). Every child known by name.
column17: verified_isbi (39.5356, -0.4247; ISBI Schools). CORRECTED from original 39.5397/-0.4062 which was approximate. Note: coordinates point to Campolivar/Godella area.
column18: 4.4 (Primary campus, 30 reviews); 4.2 (Secondary campus, 32 reviews) — listed as separate entries on Micole
column20: 4.5 (approximate, based on iSchoolAdvisor Google reviews aggregate)
column22: ~€7,150/year first-year total for age 3 (per ISD 2025/26, incl. one-time fees). Annual tuition not broken down publicly in detail — Micole lists 'more than €700/month'. 25% discount on tuition for third child. Pre-enrolment is free. Contact school for full fee schedule. Dining room with freshly prepared meals from own kitchens (fee not publicly listed). Bus routes to/from Valencia city available.
column23: ~570 students (per NABSS profile: 'around 570 pupils, combining local families and international students')
column24: One of the oldest British schools in Valencia, founded in 1976 as a British nursery in El Plantío-La Cañada in a traditional Valencian farmstead surrounded by olive trees (hence the name 'Los Olivos'). Originally followed Montessori and Freinet methodology. Run as a TEACHER COOPERATIVE (unusual structure — not a family/corporate-owned school) of highly qualified British and Spanish teachers, secular and apolitical. Two purpose-built campuses in Campolivar/Godella: Primary (C/ Pino Panera 25, built 1983, expanded with secondary wing) and Secondary (Av. de los Almendros 13, built 1996–97, first GCSE cohort June 1998). Facilities: science labs, IT rooms, music and art rooms, sports areas, dining halls with own kitchens preparing fresh meals. Extracurricular: guitar, piano, yoga, chess, robotics, dance, art, roller skating, football, basketball, tennis, rhythmic gymnastics, volleyball. OUTSTANDING ACADEMIC RESULTS (2025 session): 100% A-Level pass rate; 73% of A-Level students achieving A or A*; 96% of IGCSE students achieving 5+ A*-C/9-4 passes; 100% pass Spanish university entrance; average Spanish university entrance grade 12.08/14. Small, family-oriented school — strong community spirit emphasised by parents and alumni. Recognised as one of 19 best schools in Spain (per iSchoolAdvisor review). ~15–20 min drive NW from Valencia centre. Bus routes available.

column3: Private (1st cycle Infantil, ages 1–2) / Concertado (2nd cycle Infantil through Bachillerato — concierto singular for Bachillerato)
column4: C/ Ermita Nova, 3, 46110 Godella, Valencia, Spain (single campus)
column6: Quiet residential area of Godella, close to Valencia city with excellent road connections. Multipurpose building integrated into the residential architecture, surrounded by green areas, with classrooms bordered by trees and gardens.
column9: 1st Cycle Educación Infantil (ages 1–2, private). 2nd Cycle Educación Infantil (ages 3–5, concertado). Educación Primaria (ages 6–11, concertado). ESO - Educación Secundaria Obligatoria (ages 12–15, concertado). Bachillerato: Científico-Técnico and Humanidades y Ciencias Sociales (ages 16–18, concierto singular).
column10: Spanish national curriculum (LOMLOE). Experimental, project-based learning methodology — 'Hacer es comprender' ('Doing is Understanding'). Five differentiated levels of programming per class based on student maturity, set by the Gabinete Psicopedagógico and reviewed termly. Plans include: Plan de Convivencia, Plan de Acción Tutorial, Plan de Fomento a la Lectura, Proyecto Lingüístico del Centro, Plan de Transición between stages. University professors collaborate with departments. Student research projects (trabajos de investigación) are a core element. Robotics and Oratoria (public speaking) programmes integrated.
column11: Plurilingual programme: Spanish, Valencian, English, French. English is prioritised and integrated into several non-language subjects (Expresión Corporal, Educación Física, Ciencias Naturales, Biología, Economía). Students prepared for Cambridge English certifications (B1, B2, C1 achieved by secondary/Bachillerato students). 6 English conversation assistants in Primary alone.
column12: Spanish, Valencian, English, French. Introduction to Chinese language and culture in ESO (confirmed by Ajuntament de Godella official page).
column13: Digital learning platform Alexia used by teachers, parents, and students. Students from 4º Primaria (age 9–10) access an online collaborative learning environment complementary to classroom guides, with content libraries and collaborative materials shared by teachers. Online training and simulation programmes available. Press reports reference Chromebook 1:1 from 3º Primaria through Bachillerato — contact school to verify current device policy details.
column14: Experiential, project-based learning rooted in the motto 'Hacer es comprender' (Doing is Understanding). School as a place of 'work and research.' Formation of individuals with critical capacity and ability to intervene positively in society. Five differentiated levels per class for individualised attention. Strong emphasis on: observation, experimentation, discovery; critical thinking and communication (oratoria programme); arts integration (Expresión Corporal, Danza, Bellas Artes, Music); scientific research projects. Comprehensive Gabinete Psicopedagógico providing: psychopedagogical evaluation of all students throughout schooling; individual tracking; school and career orientation; tutorial action plan; special needs support (both reinforcement and gifted programmes). Secular, co-educational institution.
column17: approximate_godella (from original data; consistent with C/ Ermita Nova, 3 location)
column22: COMPLEX FEE STRUCTURE: Concertado stages (2nd cycle Infantil through Bachillerato): base tuition covered by government subsidy. Micole classifies as 'Gratis or <€100/month.' HOWEVER, a 2023 Garlic B2B study identified Gençana as the MOST EXPENSIVE concertado in Comunitat Valenciana with a BASE CUOTA of €450/month (which includes comedor and school materials). El Mundo ranking listed: €273.15/month for 1st cycle Infantil (private) and €25.70/month for Bachillerato (concierto singular). 1st Cycle Infantil (private): separate private fee. Dining room: own kitchen, breakfast/lunch/snack; adapted menus (coeliac, diabetic, vegetarian, vegan, macrobiotic). Annual renewal fee €445 (referenced in El Mundo data). The real cost is significantly higher than 'free' — families should request full fee breakdown directly from the school. Extended hours available 7:30–18:30.
column23: ~452 students (your original figure; consistent with school being described as having '80 personas' on staff and small cohort sizes — e.g. 17 students in 2º Bachillerato 2014/15). Website's 'De un vistazo' page lists statistics dynamically. Primary alone has 25 teachers/assistants for ~6 year groups.
column24: Highly regarded innovative school in Godella, founded 1981. Consistently ranked among BEST SCHOOLS in Spain: El Mundo 100 Mejores Colegios de España (82/100 points); PAU/Selectividad 2023: 2nd highest average in entire Comunitat Valenciana (7.94/10), behind only San Alberto Magno, Alicante (8.39). Strong critical thinking, research, and communication focus — students regularly win national/regional academic competitions: Physics Olympiad (best score in Comunitat Valenciana), Chemistry Olympiad, Cangur Mathematics prizes, Trau la Llengua literary prizes, Experimenta STEM fair awards, Concurso de Fotografía Matemática. Conselleria de Educación designation as CEPAFE (Centro Educativo Promotor de la Actividad Física y el Deporte). Cambridge English certifications through C1 level. Facilities: single campus with specialised classrooms, gymnasium, library, movement expression and music rooms, green outdoor areas with trees and gardens. Primary hours: 8:45–16:30 (Sept–June, including 4 days of Easter). Extended hours: 7:30–18:30 for families needing flexibility. Summer School (July) open to external students. Gabinete Psicopedagógico with dedicated team of psychopedagogues + PT specialist + speech therapist. University entrance prep courses offered. Collaboration with university professors across departments. CAVEATS: Some families report high academic workload may not suit all learning styles. Some negative reviews on Buscocolegio cite rigid rules, high pressure, and cliquish culture. Polarising: long-term families (20+ years) are deeply loyal; others find the environment too demanding. Most EXPENSIVE concertado in CV per 2023 Garlic B2B study (€450/month base including comedor + materials). Digital platform Alexia for parent-teacher communication and student grades tracking.

column2: CEIP Municipal Benimaclet (Colegio Público Municipal de Benimaclet)
column3: Public — MUNICIPAL (run by Ajuntament de València, not Conselleria de Educación — one of only 3 municipal primary schools in Valencia city, alongside CEIP Prof. Santiago Grisolía and CEIP Fernando de los Ríos)
column4: C/ de l'Arquitecte Arnau, s/n, 46020 València, Valencia, Spain
column6: Benimaclet (historically Valencian-speaking barrio, NE of Valencia centre; vibrant, multicultural, socially active neighbourhood near Universitat Politècnica campus de Vera)
column7: Unknown exact founding year — described as 'el más antiguo de Benimaclet' (the oldest school in Benimaclet). Founded by the Ayuntamiento de València to address the lack of schools in the area. Historical roots go back decades.
column8: 3 to 12 years (2nd cycle Infantil + Primaria only — NO secondary. Adscribed IES: IES Rascanya for secondary continuation)
column9: 2nd Cycle Educación Infantil (ages 3–5, 3 year groups). Educación Primaria (ages 6–12, Years 1–6). NOTE: Does NOT offer 1st cycle Infantil (0–2). No secondary — students transfer to IES Rascanya.
column10: Spanish national curriculum (Valencian Community / LOMLOE). Plurilingual programme: PIP (Programa d'Incorporació Progressiva / Programa de Incorporación Progresiva). Project-based learning that motivates students through their own curiosity. Cooperative and active learning prioritised. New technologies used as complement to teaching-learning process. Erasmus+ project 'Change your Mind' (international school exchanges). Municipally funded inclusive education programmes: innovation technology for special needs, occupational therapy, augmentative communication for 0–6 year olds (in collaboration with FEVADIS and Colegio de Terapeutas Ocupacionales de la CV).
column11: Plurilingual: Spanish/Valencian vehicular languages (PIP programme — progressive incorporation of Valencian); English as foreign language
column13: New technologies used as complement to teaching-learning process (school policy statement). IT classroom (Aula de Informática) available. No published 1:1 device programme — technology is integrated as a tool, not as primary medium. Contact school for current device policy specifics.
column14: Inclusive, multicultural, community-embedded public school. Motto/values: critical, independent, inclusive, flexible — 'alumnado feliz' (happy students). Project-based learning driven by student curiosity. Strong emphasis on cooperative and active learning. Distinctive programmes: TUTORÍAS AFECTIVAS — affective tutoring programme to improve social-emotional skills, reduce behavioural issues (permanent resource, the school's pride); RINCÓN VIOLETA and BANCO DE LA AMISTAD — equality and coexistence initiatives; HUERTO ESCOLAR (school garden) — four plots integrated into the curriculum from age 3 to 6º Primaria, teaching ecology, planting, weeding, watering, harvesting. Open to the neighbourhood. AFA (family association) very active in organising extracurricular activities, support programmes, and summer school (July).
column17: approximate_benimaclet (consistent with C/ Arquitecte Arnau in Benimaclet neighbourhood)
column20: 4.1 (approximate — limited Google reviews for public primary schools)
column21: ~30–50 (estimated; public CEIPs typically have few Google reviews)
column22: FREE (public municipal school). No tuition fees. Dining room: 220 places, own kitchen (cocina propia) — fee set by Ayuntamiento, typically ~€4–5/day for municipal schools. Escola Matinera (early morning care before school hours) and Escola Vespertina (afternoon care) available — fees set by municipal services. Summer school organised by AFA during July. Ayuntamiento doubles school meal grants (becas de comedor) per recent policy. €2.4M annual municipal budget for maintenance of all 3 municipal primary schools.
column23: ~450 students (capacity: 150 Infantil places + 300 Primaria places, per Ayuntamiento de València official data from open day announcement). Highly diverse: ~27% foreign students in Infantil, ~41% foreign students in Primaria (per PEC document). Many Spanish students also from other autonomous communities or families without Valencian.
column24: Oldest school in Benimaclet, founded by Ayuntamiento de València. MUNICIPAL school — one of only THREE municipal CEIPs in Valencia city (rare status; most public schools are managed by Conselleria/Generalitat, not the city). U-shaped building, 2 floors. Very well-regarded by parents: Micole 4.6/5 (highest-rated public CEIP in database for Valencia). DISTINCTIVE FEATURES: Huerto Escolar (school garden) with 4 plots, integrated into curriculum from Infantil to 6º Primaria — all groups rotate through growing seasons; Tutorías Afectivas (affective mentoring — permanent emotional support programme); Rincón Violeta + Banco de la Amistad (equality and friendship initiatives); Erasmus+ 'Change your Mind' international project. Gabinete Psicopedagógico with orientation services, speech therapist (maestra de audición y lenguaje), and social worker (educación compensatoria). Inclusive education programmes funded by Ayuntamiento: technology innovation for early detection of special needs, occupational therapy in schools, augmentative communication for ages 0–6. Very active AFA (family association) organising extracurricular activities within the school. School hours: Mon–Thu 9:00–12:30 and 15:00–16:30; Fri 9:00–14:00; Sept/June 9:00–13:00. Library, music room, multipurpose hall, sports facilities. Adscribed IES for secondary: IES Rascanya. LIMITATIONS: Only goes to 6º Primaria (age 12) — families must transition to a public IES for secondary; limited Google/Micole review base (only 10 Micole reviews) despite high rating; being a public municipal school means staffing subject to municipal budget/politics. Located in popular Benimaclet neighbourhood — walkable, metro-connected, near UPV campus.
